I’d like to thank the @televisionacad for giving us a seat at the table to advocate for authentic Jewish representation. In a time of rising antisemitism, this work is more important than ever. #jewishrepresentationmatters

Today something pretty historic happened. At the @televisionacad (the Emmy’s) diversity, equity and inclusion summit I sat for about an hour and heard about marginalized minority groups who are depicted negatively on screen and endangered in life and no one mentioned Jews (except for one quick utterance of antisemitism in a list). 

So they asked us to share any topics that had been missed and I took the mic and explained that I was sitting through a conference on diversity and inclusion and felt completely invisible, even though antisemitic attacks are the highest they’ve been since tracking started in 1979. Our 2% of the population receives 60% of the religious hate crimes. I said the Jews started Hollywood (and noted that you can say “the Jews,” even though Chappelle said you can’t) because of persecution, but they baked their self-hatred into so many characters. And I’m sick of the tropes and caricatures and as an orthodox Jewish woman, my family and I are identifiable on the streets and I’m sick of only seeing the most insufferable people from my community or only seeing them be heroic when they leave. I told them that when my son saw footage of Jews being attacked around the world a couple summers ago, he cried, asking why he had to be born to such a hated people. 

And I told them that  it’s time that we start telling proud Jewish stories. 

One by one every jew in the room (none were there for Jewish advocacy) came up and thanked me for saying the thing out loud  that they’ve wanted to say for so long. Several non-Jews thanked me too. And I got a lot of business cards. 😎

The thing about being a Jew, watching out for antisemitism, as we’ve all been conditioned to do, is that if you get too worried too early, you may be pronounced crazy. And if you get too worried too late, you may be pronounced dead. 

I recently saw a tweet that said that if you think Jews are neurotic, it’s because we’re all descended from folks, who a couple hundred years ago said, “Not liking the vibe here, let’s get on a boat.” That’s partially true.

Some of us are descended from folks who didn’t realize quite how bad the vibe was and consequently became sole survivors of decimated families.

But Jews are too privileged, too powerful they say…

(Link in bio for the full article!)

In the midst of running around from DC to LA advocating against antisemitism in media through our Keter branch, our Makom branch has been planning a shabbaton. One of our sessions this shabbos will be how you deal with rising Jew hatred when you have your own complicated feelings about being Jewish. We’re here to unpack that. Meanwhile, our Tikun branch is working to repair the systemic issues that made being Jewish painful to so many Makom members. 

It’s a lot. Our three branches are each their own universes. And they’re also all totally connected. At Jew in the City, we change negative perceptions of Jews and replace those feelings with love and pride. It’s our Annual Campaign now, the one time of year we ask you to go from consumer of content to builder of world changing. Join us at whatever level you can by clicking in the link in our bio.

We stumbled upon Ruchy Lebovits’s Instagram account – @ruchyl_photography – by happy accident. After scrolling through her page, we knew we had to talk with her and introduce our followers to her and her platform.

What is unique about her photography portfolio? There are many family photographers in the world, but Ruchy has carved out a special niche of family photography: one that expresses Chasidic joy.

Upon making aliyah from Monsey about nine years ago, Ruchy was awe-struck by the diversity and beauty of Jewishness in Israel – particularly in the Chasidic community. As an artist with a camera, Ruchy’s portfolio is full of family portraits of Chasidic Jews: each subject is smiling, joy radiating from their faces. 

Read more about this story and see more photos with the link in our bio. #hasidic #hasidim #jewishrepresentation

One thing that isn’t well known about Chanukah is that the menorah in the Temple had been damaged by the Greeks, and the Maccabees had to construct another a brand new one in order to light the oil. The Talmud (Menochos 28b) discusses that this makeshift one was constructed from either wood or iron spits, so it was a lot more shabby when compared to the real menorah! If God was making a miracle already with enabling the oil to last for eight whole nights, why couldn’t He make a miracle and restore the menorah to its former glory as well? Link to article in bio. @itsgilaross

Many people mistakenly think the Torah is at odds with science. However, let’s take the origin of the universe. Although scientists used to believe the universe always existed, with the invention of the Hubble Telescope, they heard the echo of the Big Bang. Suddenly science and Judaism were aligned. The universe had a beginning!

Watch the full video on our YouTube! Link in bio: “Science vs. Religion, Mayim Bialik And The Other Big Bang Theory”

#jewinthecity #science #judaism #bible #torah

When we made the first Jew in the City video in 2005, no one else was using social media to show the beauty and meaning in the Orthodox Jewish community. 17 years later, our work has influenced many other Orthodox Jews to proudly showcase their lives on social media. Changing Hollywood was always the ultimate dream. If social media can reach millions, Hollywood can reach BILLIONS. 

In less than a year since our first meeting, the Jew in the City Hollywood Bureau - the first and only Jewish Bureau - which advocates for whole and human depictions of Jews on tv, movies and streaming services, has met with nearly everyone there is to meet in the entertainment world! We have explained to these organizations and companies that there’s a problem with Jewish depictions and those problematic depictions are harming Jews. 

In 2023, the plan will be to prove the problem with data and start training showrunners and movie executives on how they can do better. When we make this change, the impact of increased Jewish pride and combatting antisemitism will be tremendous, beH. It’s our Annual Campaign now and when you support our work, you are our partner in these historic changes. Our goal was to take on Hollywood, and we got there. Help us keep going! Link to campaign in bio.

While the word “sufganiya” is a relatively modern term, the root of the word and all its variations is “sofgan” and “sfogga.” In the Talmud, this refers to “spongy dough.” The history continues via the writings of Rabbi Maimon ben Yosef (father of Rabbi Moshe Maimonedes) in the 12th century, in which he writes about the importance of consuming “sofganim” to commemorate Chanukah and its miracles. “One must not make light of the custom of eating sofganim on Chanukah. It is a custom of the Kadmonim [the ancient ones].” 

Jews who were forced to flee and make their lives in other countries have adopted and adapted their host culture’s fried delicacies. For example, the fritters mentioned by Rabbi Maimon ben Yosef were likely a sweet, syrup-coated pancake, which is quite different from the contemporary jelly-filled donut, and even more dissimilar to the artisanal donuts that have become popular in the past few years. The journey from sofganim to the modern sufganiyot is a long and winding one — and luckily an utterly delicious one!

The last four years have been the most deadly against Jews in US history, starting with Jews being murdered in synagogues, like Tree of Life and Poway Chabad, then kosher stores, with Jersey City shooting, then private Jewish homes, with the Monsey machete attack. May all of their memories be for a blessing. May we see an end to Jew hatred in our lifetime. 

#monseystabbing #stopantisemitism #endjewhatred

Every year on Chanukah, we say the words of Al Ha Nisim in our daily prayers: “We thank You also for the miracles, for the redemption, for the mighty deeds and saving acts, wrought by You, as well as for the wars which You waged for our ancestors in days of old, at this season.”

In Makom (a branch of Jew in the City where disenfranchised Haredi Jews can find a positive place in Judaism), we recently brought therapist Dr. Rachel Lowinger to speak to our members about healing from trauma through the lens of Chanukah. What we've discovered in our 7 years of programming is that most Makom members are trauma survivors and survivors of childhood emotional neglect.

Dr. Lowinger began her lecture invoking Al Ha Nisim. She said we'd expect to thank God for the miracles and the redemption and the salvation. But why the wars? Why would we thank God for having to do battles? 

Dr. Lowinger beautifully explained that our battles become part of our stories. We would never ask for them if we had the choice, but if battles and trauma come our way, they can be a way for us to become exceptional people, allowing us to shine a personal light to the world that no one else has to offer. 

#chanukah #chanukahwisdom #alhanisim #jewishwisdom

Thank you @washingtonpost for reminding us that “Jews are vectors of disease.” This picture in Brooklyn has nothing to do with an outbreak in Ohio, which has occurred in Columbus’s large Somali community. “Most of the sickened children — 78 percent — are Black, 6 percent are Asian, 6 percent are White, and 4 percent are Hispanic, according to Columbus officials.”

Why don’t you fire the antisemite on your staff who did this.

UPDATE- they fixed it!

Hey @oxunipress @google - your online dictionary has an antisemitism problem. First definition of Jew should be “the children of Abraham, who ended child sacrifice and brought the Ten Commandments to the world, made countless contributions to humanity in their thousands year existence, despite constant persecution.” Or something like that.

A Jew with horns and Jews as vectors of diseases continue to populate Western mainstream media in nearly 2023. It is absolutely awful and we will continue all channels of our advocacy work. Link in bio. 

Or at https://jewinthecity.com/2022/12/netflix-puts-horns-on-jew-washpo-libels-jews-as-vectors-of-disease/

Just saw @leopoldstadtbwy - it’s a story about how a Jew can never stop being a Jew and how success and wealth one day can be stripped away the next. It began with a Jewish star being placed on a Christmas tree and 1899 Vienna felt a lot like 21st century America. 

It’s based on playwright, Tom Stoppard’s, story of not knowing he was a Jew or that all 4 of his grandparents died in the Holocaust until he was in his 50’s. The discussion of Israel throughout gave some glimmers of hope in an otherwise really heavy story. The Jewish family traditions, like the Passover Seder, were delightful to watch being performed on a Broadway stage. This is about as relevant as could be now, the family not knowing how soon is too soon to leave. It was just extended in theater until July. See it while you can. #leopoldstadt

Looking forward to speaking at the @nefeshinternational mental health conference this Wednesday night on religious trauma, alongside Yitzi Horowitz LCSW. 

Makom is not a mental health program and to be honest, I had no idea what we were getting into when we launched this branch of Jew in the City to help disenfranchised Haredi Jews find a positive place in Orthodoxy back in 2015. 

8 years and many hundreds of courageous members later, I have learned a lot about how the Torah can be corrupted by dysfunctional and toxic people to hurt innocent ones. 

The stories of our Makom members are the lynchpin of our organization. They provide the framework for the issues we are working to fix in our Tikun branch. Their painful stories are also what so much anti-Jewish media covers. These are the abusive cases in the community, not Torah, when it’s practiced as it’s meant to be. 

Giving mental health professionals many examples of how religion can be used to traumatize and what possible ways we can heal the hurt and prevent it, are topics that are very near to my heart. 

I’ve spoken to more mental health professionals over the years, than I ever intended to, as we developed our Code of Conduct and Membership Agreement to make sure Makom is a safe space, has appropriate boundaries and that we know when a member has needs beyond what we can offer. But a special shout out to our in-house PsyD @madsenpsych who has been my patient and hilarious teacher all these years.

Netflix recently put horns on a Jew. This practice has over 1000 years of precedent in Western media. Here’s the scoop.

After so much bitter division in our country, the right and the left have finally come together! To unite against the Jews. White Supremacists with tiki torches, famously shouted “Jews will not replace us,” a few years ago in Charlottesville. While they are the most extreme on the right, don’t believe that a more quiet version of this doesn’t exist beyond such marches.

On the left, having too much power and wealth means a person has taken too big of a slice. It is then a mitzvah to even things out. And the prevailing perception on the left is that Jews are not marginalized because we have too much power and wealth. And we need to be cut down to size. Universities and places of work are beginning to do that work. Which harkens back to a time not that long ago in a place not too far away…

Which leads me to a play my husband and I recently saw on Broadway: Leopoldstadt.

Read further on our website at: https://jewinthecity.com/2023/01/antisemitism-increasing-in-us-workplace-bloomberg-reports/

Link in bio.
Jews have been portrayed as vectors of disease for millennia. How could this be continuing in progressive America?

“Ma rabu maasecha Hashem” - How great are your wonders, God.” Got separated from our group today while ATVing and faced one of the most terrifying moments in my life. We got to an extremely steep rocky incline. I was sure it was not traversable, but my group misunderstood where we were when we called for help and told me they had all done it. I tried to go up, and the vehicle began slipping. I told them I CANNOT do this, but they said “just give it more gas. You can do it.” And I did. And we got up. And I don’t actually know how. 

When we returned the ATVs, they told us this incline was not meant for going up - only going down. We also had to go down. It was so terrifying my son was saying shema in order to stay calm and not as a joke. 

We were surrounded by tremendous natural beauty throughout the trails, but the spark within every single one of us, to rise above our fears and face impossible situations and come out successfully, is just as breathtaking as the views captured here. We are also the wondrous creations of God. Ma rabu maasecha, Hashem. 

#atving #atv #sedona #sedonaarizona # #faith #tehillim #psalms

I had known a Jewish black woman from school, who was graduating just as I was arriving, so we didn’t have much overlap or have too many interactions. There was one thing that I did know about her, though: she was a convert. Later, a different black woman reached out to us at Jew in the City and said she was strongly considering converting.

She wanted to know if there was racism in the Orthodox community. I told her, “You will find some very closed-minded people, and that is really a shame. But there are also many people, like myself, who are open-minded, non-judgmental and appreciate diversity.” To help her out even more, I decided to connect her with the black convert who I knew from years ago so she could give her the inside scoop. 

Read further on our blog at: https://jewinthecity.com/2016/01/black-jews-discovering-a-prejudice-i-didnt-know-i-had/

Link in bio.

Jew in the City is making its debut appearance at the @sundanceorg Film Festival and we’d love for you to attend our panel - a conversation between @malinasaval Features Editor at @variety and JITC founder and Executive Director, Allison Josephs. 

Why have Jews been left out of DEI conversations? Everyone believes Jews are vastly over represented in Hollywood, is that true? Why is their representation so often inauthentic, relying on caricatures at best and evil depictions at worst? How did Hollywood’s founders, escaping antisemitism, bake their complicated feelings of Judaism into so many storylines? How can we finally change the narrative so that rising Jew hatred will be replaced with an explosion of Jewish pride?

Please register with us in link in bio or at

https://jitc.zohobackstage.com/SundanceFilmFestivalMeJew
where you'll be instructed to create your Festival Account in order to scan your Festival ID at the door. This event is first come, first served and no ticket is required. Please arrive 15 minutes early to secure your spot in line. https://jitc.zohobackstage.com/SundanceFilmFestivalMeJew

How did Hollywood’s founders, escaping antisemitism, bake their complicated feelings of Judaism into so many storylines? How can we finally change the narrative so that rising Jew-hatred will be replaced with an explosion of Jewish pride? #sundancefilmfestival2023

He was 38 years old, and she was 36. They had 11 children together. Link in bio or at: https://jewinthecity.com/2023/01/the-importance-of-faith-in-the-face-of-tragedy/

The non-Hasidic father and son then removed their yarmulkes for fear of being targeted. This is the second time in a week I’ve seen posts about @delta targeting visible Jews on planes. Maybe they need some sensitivity training. #endjewhatred #stopantisemitism

The following movie review began with angry texts I sent to friends and colleagues yesterday, as I was watching You People, the number one movie now streaming on Netflix. It premiered on Holocaust Remembrance Day, and I’ve got to hand it to them on the timing: nothing says #neveragain like #rightnow.

There are numerous spoilers below, but when a movie starts out so rotten, it is impossible to ruin it. If I had to sum up the most basic problem with You People, it wouldn’t be the abundant Holocaust jokes, like Ezra buying a small diamond for his fiancé, and deciding that he’ll lie that it’s his grandmother’s “from the Holocaust.” You know, “the Holocaust” – the get out of jail free card for every Jew. 

Link to article in bio. 

@youpeoplenetflix #youpeoplereviews

UPDATE: this ad is being targeted to Jews on Facebook feeds specifically and was made by a Jewish ad agency. Other minority groups are also getting targeted ads. Here are a few takeaways from this ad:

1) @njdeptofhealth social platforms should include positive messages about Jews, like they do for other minority communities. They should also show happy Jewish families throughout their feeds, like they do for other marginalized groups. If their goal is diversity in their regular ads, Jews should be included for the good times and not only when it comes time to mention not spreading disease. 

2) Even content made by well-meaning Jews can miss the mark because an issue is really sensitive. Purim 2020 got labeled as a super spreader event, but I just checked St. Patrick Day celebrations in 2020. They happened all over the country at the exact same time as Purim, but there was no blaming of Irish people as being vectors of disease. 

3) With Mayor de Blasio calling out Jews by name during Covid  to the recent @washingtonpost article on a Somali measles spread, using images on only Hasidic Jews, plus millennia of tropes of Jews being disease spreaders, if we’re sensitive on this topic, we have a reason to be.

People often ask me how I have the confidence to speak up for the Jewish people, how I have the guts to take on Hollywood. Although popular media will assure you that it is Judaism that silences women, when I look at our holy books, I find women, like Queen Esther, as a role model to derive courage from. Esther was young, she was an orphan, she was the wife of the king of Persia but also his prisoner. 

If Esther could take on the largest empire in her world at the time, surely I (and all Jewish women) have been given permission, nay an exhortation to speak up when we have the chance in our lives. 

Today we fast to remember Esther’s courage. Let’s all bring a piece of that courage to every other day of the year. (On set, before filming my interview with @chrisccuomo last month.)

#taanisesther #strongjewishwomen #womenofcourage #esther #purim

The story of an evil man trying to destroy a bunch of outcasts, saved by a brave young woman and the Hand that watched over her. Purim is almost #Wednesday this year and the Jewish people are forevermore. Happy Purim!

The name's meaning may surprise you - Purim is named to commemorate Haman’s decision to annihilate the Jews. In his plan, he decided to use a lottery system to decide on which date they were going to die. It’s such a small part of the story, you could be forgiven for not even noticing it. So why does it warrant the festival being named for how Haman decided on the date of the Jew’s destruction? Read further at the link in our bio or at: https://jewinthecity.com/2023/03/how-haman-used-purim-lots-to-terrorize-jews/

LOYAL, BRAVE, TRUE 

#internationalwomensday nearly coincides with Purim - the holiday where a female Jewish heroine saved her people. Maybe it’s not a coincidence. 

Last year I saw the live-action #Mulan and I was mesmerized: the choreography, the cinematography- the heroine featured by talented female filmmakers: and Mulan’s virtues: loyal, brave, true. I was high on #girlpower 

I immediately looked up the story and was disappointed to see there was never a real Mulan. But then I got to thinking - as Jew, I have my own heroines who were loyal, brave and true. 

On the warrior side, the judge and prophetess Devorah prophesied that a woman would bring the downfall of the evil Sisera, which the brave and mighty Yael did by driving a stake into his head, over 1000 years before Mulan supposedly lived. 

And then we have the heroine of the #Purim story - #QueenEsther. Like Mulan, she concealed her identity. But then there was about to be a Holocaust - the entire Jewish people had their fate signed and sealed. 

Esther was quietly hiding as a gentile and could have saved herself. But she was loyal, brave, and true, and revealed her real identity to save her people, putting herself in physical and spiritual harm in order to do so. 

I am often told that as an Orthodox Jewish woman that I am oppressed. But it is not true. I am empowered. And so much of the pride I hold as a Jewish woman comes from the Jewish heroines we’ve been celebrating for thousands of years.

The Talmud tells us to do something strange on Purim: drink until you don’t know the difference between “blessed is Mordechai” and “cursed is Haman” (“ad d’lo yada”). This is a surprising statement. Judaism generally doesn’t promote getting drunk. And why would we want to be confused about not knowing the difference between blessing Mordechai (the hero of the Purim story) and cursing Haman (the villain of it)? Why do we need to drink in order to do this?

Perhaps the answer can be found in the modern day antisemitism landscape. There are certain types – Nazis, white supremacists, Kanye West – who are easy to call out. Speaking out against this type of antisemite is uncontroversial. It’s what my friend calls “antisemitism-lite.” Some groups and Jewish leaders stick to this safe approach. That’s not to say that this isn’t a concerning group. Kanye has a huge following, and his unabashed praising of Hitler encouraged a lot of antisemites, who had been in hiding, to feel comfortable to say the quiet part out loud. White supremacists also have a penchant for shooting up synagogues, which is pretty horrific. But there’s a danger in not venturing deeper into the other, less comfortable, Jew-hating dynamics. Because the problems you don’t speak about or deal with fester and metastasize. 

Read more in link in bio.

My family is in Spain for Pesach. From the moment we got off the plane, I felt a heaviness, contemplating what was done to my ancestors in this place. As far as I know, I am not Sephardic, but the Jewish people are a family. Just because one branch  sought refuge in Spain 2000 years ago, when we were violently exiled from the land of Israel, doesn’t make me any less connected to their fate.

And speaking of those Jews who arrived in Toledo 2000 years ago, there is a theory that they named the city Toledo from the Hebrew word “Toldot,” generations. They expected to be in this place for generations. They called it “the new Jerusalem,” just like the Jews of Germany said of Berlin. Things never seem to end well when we get too comfortable in a foreign land and mistakenly believe it’s our forever home.

We visited several old cities here, each with “Jewish quarters,” but with no remnants of anything particularly old and Jewish, besides some out-of-use synagogues that have been turned into churches and even a clothing store. In Segovia, beneath the most charming castle, lies a Jewish graveyard, where potatoes are now growing on top of Jewish bodies. Spaniards desecrated us in our life and do so in our death.

The Jewish museums are full of “artifacts” that are meant to demonstrate what Jewish life might have looked like before 1500 years of Spanish Jewish life was brought to a crushing halt, before the country was made Judenrein. But these artifacts are mostly modern day Judaica, put out on display, since Jews are so rare here.

They don’t teach the Spanish Inquisition in most schools in Spain despite the fact that it lasted for 360 years! They had a couple Inquisition museums at one point, but they closed them because they made Spaniards uncomfortable. I’ll bet.

Walking through these streets, looking visibly Jewish, I feel almost as if we are ghosts. A people who used to be here, but was destroyed and forgotten about long ago. A Jewish museum guide told us that most Spaniards know nothing about Spain’s Jewish history or even Jews themselves, other than Krusty the Clown from The Simpsons…
Link to article in bio. #spain #antisemitism #inquisition

Girona felt different than some of the other cities we visited in Spain. They have a sizable number of Jewish artifacts. We saw a 13th cent hagaddah. They unearthed a mikvah. There are holes for mezuzot in random blocks all over since bricks were repurposed. The Jews paid the king to protect them. In 1300’s, the king had the Jews trapped in the ghetto for 17 weeks. If you converted, you could leave and be safe. Our ancestors sacrificed so much for us to be here today as Jews, still learning those pages of Talmud, affixing mezuzos to our doors, telling the exodus at our Passover Seder, using the mikvah, burying our loved ones in Jewish cemeteries. And speaking of burial, visiting the other cities that had almost no remnants of Jewish life felt like mourning a loved one when there is no body. 

Today in Girona, we could touch our ancestors’ lives, through the artifacts they left behind. And they can look down on us knowing that we are keeping the tradition alive. 

One more special note. An old Jewish tombstone was being used as a trough until someone realized what it was, and the museum acquired it. Look at this moving inscription, which reminds us of the tragic recent deaths in Israel, because being Jewish isn’t linear-it’s interconnected:

“I will cry, lament and sing elegies thinking of mother and brothers. They were dejected and dismayed on the day he was laid to rest. The servants, the Sun, and the stars in the heavens felt afflicted and arrayed themselves in darkness. May his soul be at rest in a better place along with those who
sing praises in the House of God."
The seventeenth day of the month of Sivan in the year four thousand and 958 of the Creation of the world: a day of anguish, darkness and gloom, when the charming and chosen Rabbi Shlomoh was called to the Celestial Community. Blessed be the memory of the twenty-two years old son of the noble rabbi Josef ben Tega. They will cry bitterly for him and their bitterness will be that of losing a first-born child. May peace be upon the resting place of he who walked in rectitude. May he rest and rise again to receive his reward at the end of time. Amen.”
Girona, Montjuic, Sivan 17th, 4958 (May-June, 1198)

We were told that it’s not safe to wear a yarmulke publicly in Barcelona (the BDS stronghold of Spain), but we didn’t listen since Jews have done enough hiding in this country. 

And just for fun, the non-discrimination office in town displays a host of diverse languages. There was one they didn’t see fit to include. 

#spain #barcelona #endjewhatred #proudjews

More erasure of Jews found in Barcelona, in the form of a cemetery being desecrated, the tombstones being repurposed as bricks (notice Hebrew letters on random bricks), the mikvah having a souvenir shop built over it (the word “Banys” tells us there was a bath here) and apartments built over a synagogue. 

I got more clarity on the disputations and Inquisition and the absolute necessity for Jews to have their own land. 

The Jews paid taxes to the king for their safety. The Catholics paid taxes to the church. Jews were only 10% of the population, but they were so wealthy, their share was as much as the 90% the Catholics paid. The church was jealous of what the Jews were paying the king so they said the Jews should all convert. The king didn’t want to lose his money, so he suggested that a great sage called the Ramban debate a former Jew, who became an apostate-Pablo Christiani. The disputation lasted 4 days, the rabbi ended with such a strong argument the king could only say “well argued but the rabbi is wrong,” as opposed to a rebuttal. In 1391, 400 Jews were killed in riots. The Jews of Barcelona were gone 100 yrs before Inquisition due to murder, conversion or leaving. 
 

Back to the Inquisition: The Jews had funded king’s war against the Moors and Columbus’s expedition to the New World. The king and queen did not want to repay their debts, so they simply began a process where Jews had to leave and lose everything or die and lose everything or be imprisoned and lose everything. If they converted, they could still be accused of being Jewish and lose everything. 

Which leads me to the horrifying murders in Israel. We want nothing more than to live peacefully on a little sliver of our ancestral homeland - which the world makes so hard. But relying on non-Jewish countries to keep us and protect us simply does not last. We only believe this if we don’t bother to learn our history. Every country, even the ones where we lived in relative safety for a long time, eventually robbed us, murdered us and expelled us. Then, only traces of our story remain. We must not be asleep at the wheel. Seeing our past up close has made me even more sure about my family’s future.

I couldn’t imagine a more enjoyable and meaningful way to live other than being an Orthodox Jew. The world’s understanding of our lifestyle has been filtered through utter ignorance or mistakenly believing that dysfunctional and abusive experiences of select Orthodox Jews represent Judaism itself. 

With so much love for my way of life, it was a given that I would pass these teachings, beliefs and traditions onto my children, who thank God, also love their heritage. 

But in the midst of our wonderful Pesach celebration, our joy and happiness was disrupted first by the painful Jewish history of Spain and then by the news out of Israel last week, where a family much like ours, had their mother and two daughters brutally executed by a terrorist on the way to their Pesach vacation for the crime of being Jews in their ancestral homeland.

Here we are, bringing the next generation into this way of life, knowing that acts of violence against Jews, especially those who show their Jewishness publicly, are increasing at a frightening pace. The Jews of Spain also seemed to live beautiful, meaningful lives, until they didn’t. 

Take a moment to read Rabbi Leo Dee’s message to the world in the wake of half of his family being decimated last week. He is a hero in our times. Being an observant Jew isn’t only about rituals, having nice values or being exhorted to enjoy all of the kosher physical pleasures of the world. It also about having a God to lean on and trust in in our darkest times and the wisdom to frame it all. So while there is a greater risk in living as a Jew, there is no better way to equip my children to have the faith and strength to be able to overcome whatever life throws their way. 

We are now counting the days to receiving the Torah. All Jews should merit to delight in their heritage, either by learning about it the first time or relearning it through a healthy and meaningful lens. If the world is so hellbent on hating us, we should respond with the same level of commitment to loving our Jewish identities. 

May that love lead to peace, unity, and redemption speedily in our days. 

Shabbat shalom, Good Shabbos.

A few years ago, we had a shabbos meal with a man who had moved his whole family to Israel. He was now a grandfather and he was watching his grandchildren grow up in the Holy Land. 

Towards the end of the meal, he read these verses and began to weep. He said “We are the people the Navi (prophet) spoke about. We have merited to live to see this day.”

I don’t believe in “proving” faith. I believe there are reasons to believe and reasons to doubt and that faith is ultimately a choice. But when I think of this man recognizing that he lived to see a millennial old prophecy come true, it is hard not to believe. 

For two thousand years, we prayed and cried and promised to return. And then one day, we did. 

#yomyerushalayim #yerushalayim #israel #cityofgold #miracles

Founded out of personal frustration in 2007, our organization challenges the media’s representation of Orthodox Jews. As someone raised as a proud conservative Jew, I had limited exposure to the Orthodox community, relying solely on media portrayals of the crooks, creeps, and extremists. It wasn’t until my teenage years when I had the opportunity to meet Orthodox Jews in person that I realized the truth. Behind the negative headlines, I discovered a multitude of happy, healthy individuals leading quiet lives filled with purpose and meaning. Jew in the City was born from a mission to change the narrative and showcase the beauty often overlooked in Orthodox Jewish lifestyles. 

This clip is from our interview with Aleeza Ben Shalom, star of Netflix’s “Jewish Matchmaking”, a show we consider a new standard for portraying the true beauty and humanity within the Jewish population. I had the privilege of sharing the stage once again with the brilliant and hilarious @malinasaval - features editor at @variety  We were honored by @jnfusa as women standing up for Israel. As I mentioned in my speech, this organization has literally made the desert of Israel bloom, fulfilling millennia old prophecies. Malina and I got to reprise our @sundanceorg panel discussing antisemitism in Hollywood. I will always stand up for Israel - the people of Israel, the Torah of Israel and the land of Israel. They are inseparable and they belong to every Jew 💕.

It was a beautiful day at the @jcrcny_celebrateisrael parade. At first I was struck by a float of Holocaust survivors. What a miracle for people who had their host countries give them over to their enemies and participate in their annihilation, merit to see the Jewish people return to their ancestral homeland, to have a safe haven, after 2000 years of wandering. 

Then, I noticed the children, so many Jewish children, from a wide range of backgrounds, being raised to love the land of our forefathers, even as present day enemies of the Jews work to demonize Israel. I was grateful to see our governor and mayor publicly showing their support for the Jewish state, even as their is a terrifying trend to delegitimize Israel among politicians. 

Perhaps what struck me most today was that our oldest daughter was not at the parade this year because she now lives in Israel and our second to oldest had her final march today.  She plans to go to Israel next year and make it her home as well. What a successful way to march - start off on 5th Avenue and end by bringing the words of our prophets to fruition. #celebrateisrael #israel

I hopped onto NY Presbyterian Hospital Facebook page, curious to see if their exclusion of Jews continued beyond the patient experience.

It did.

I became increasingly annoyed.

I saw a posting for Juneteenth, Pride Month, Trans-visibility Day, AAPI Month, but NOT Jewish Heritage Month (even though both are in May). There was a posting for Black History Month, the Chinese New Year, but NOT the Jewish New Year. There were various postings about women, Hispanic Heritage Month. The hospital even posted for #NationalPetDay, but did not post about Jews anywhere. At least in my grandfather’s time, Jews and dogs would be grouped together (when being banned from spaces), but even dogs seem to get more preference than Jews these days.

And the thing is, maybe we shouldn’t be surprised at all. Just like Spain had an Inquisition of Jews that lasted over 360 years, yet they “forgot” to include Hebrew on their anti-discrimination office sign in Barcelona (when fifteen plus other languages were included), so too, the hospital system had an antisemitic past and seems to have an antisemitic present.

Click the link in our bio or visit https://jewinthecity.com/2023/06/jews-excluded-at-ny-presbyterian-a-hospital-that-practices-inclusion/ to read the whole story

In 2010, at 28 years old @lalshareef decided to study abroad in France as a way to learn French. He decided to stay with a host family in France as a way to fully immerse himself. When a family is assigned to a student, the religion is never disclosed. While Alshareef wrote that he would prefer a Muslim family who was Moroccan or Algerian, that was the only preference. When he walked up to the house and saw a Magen David on the door, he was a bit in shock and requested a transfer.

“I didn’t feel comfortable to be honest,” he shares. “We heard all these things in the media that if a Jew even gives you water, it might be poisoned, I’m sorry to say that now but it was my reality.”

The school said he could transfer, but it would take two weeks to do so. During those two weeks, Alshareef’s eyes were opened to the truth about Jews. The mother in the family he stayed with was warm, compassionate and so different from the false depictions he was brainwashed to believe. 

“The mother was so wise, she took my own shock in a very wise manner and that family became the reason why I changed. My eyes were wide open to Judaism and Hebrew and I canceled the transfer.”

Click the link in our bio or visit https://jewinthecity.com/2023/06/this-muslim-man-is-changing-the-way-arabs-view-jewish-people-and-israel/ to listen to the full interview!

#muslimjewishsolidarity #arabjewishunity #jewinthecity

I tried to get there yesterday, but extreme thunderstorms in the Midwest created chaos in flights all over the country and after being stuck in the airport for over seven hours, my flight was canceled! 

Fortunately, our JITC Hollywood Bureau rep, @cindyfkaplan has boots on the ground in LA and was able to make today’s summit. 

As I posted about months ago, at the last @televisionacad DEIA Summit, when they asked if they had forgotten anything in the conversation, I grabbed the mic and told the room that they had forgotten the Jews. 

I explained why Jews are a historically and currently marginalized group and why we need a seat at the table when discussing authentic representation and accommodations. 

Not only did every Jew in the room thank me after my impassioned speech back in November, several non-Jews thanked me for educating them. And some projects already came about due to the speech. 

What also came about was that the @televisionacad had a panel on antisemitism and why Jewish representation matters in today’s summit. They got me a delicious kosher meal that I sadly wasn’t able to eat! 

We are so grateful to the folks over at the Television Academy, who are partnering with us to change the landscape of inclusion and accommodation of Jews in DEIA entertainment spaces. This is what moving the needle looks like and we’re just getting started! #jewishrepresentation #jewsindeia #televisionacademy

On this #July4 #independenceday there is another freedom we can now celebrate. By a unanimous decision, #scotus ruled that employers must accommodate Sabbath observers, as long as there is not a substantial burden. This accommodation took almost 250 years since our founding to come about! 

For generations, Shabbos observant Jews would be fired from their jobs every Friday, when they informed their bosses that they wouldn’t be coming in the next day, only to have to find a new job every Monday. 

Read some of these stories below and learn why this accommodation took so long to come about. More in depth legal analysis by first amendment attorney can be found in link in bio or https://jewinthecity.com/2023/07/historic-sabbath-scotus-ruling-builds-on-founding-freedom-of-religion/

The Jewish people value life and peace in the most profound ways. Our people have prayed thrice daily for 2000 years since our violent exile from Israel to return to it. Since the miraculous founding of the State of Israel in 1948, enemies of Jews have been plotting our destruction, even though all we want is a tiny sliver of land to be safe in. The fight against Israel isn’t only a physical one. There is an onslaught from major media outlets to portray Jews as bloodthirsty baby-killers. These ancient tropes, these blood libels take a different form than they did in the Middle Ages, but the basic theme is always the same.

It’s #sharkweek on @discovery so we’d like to introduce to Yakira Herskowitz @yakirabee an orthodox Jewish shark scientist!

It’s not really surprising that there aren’t many Orthodox Jewish shark scientists. In fact, for many of Herskowitz’s colleagues, she was the first Jew they ever met. 

“I’ve been so lucky to have such understanding, open-minded and honestly amazing colleagues,” she explains. While yes, she’s had to miss some shark dives due to Shabbat and has to bring her own food on any and all explorations, she’s become more grateful about being an Orthodox Jew through that. 

Throughout her journey in school leading up until now, she was told many times she wouldn’t be able to do it. “[So] many people told me, you’re a religious, orthodox female, you can’t do that,” she says. “It propelled me to say, ‘Yes, I can.’

Orthodox Jews love sushi. A lot. We have sushi at our pizza shops, at our steakhouses, at our bar mitzvahs and at our weddings. I always wonder what it would be like if Japanese people loved the gefilte fish the way Jews love sushi. My husband saw a show about #omakase years ago and wanted to try it. There was a kosher restaurant that was supposed to have it but it never actually happened. So when I heard that @finsandscalessushi had opened a #kosheromakase restaurant at @chabadloft in #soho and they invited me and a plus one to try their food, I knew this was the perfect birthday celebration for a man that loves atypical experiences! And what an experience it was!

Four couples sit around the table for a 15 course meal! Utensils discouraged. Eating the sushi in one bite, encouraged! Check and check! The fish selections include fatty tuna, sea bass, red snapper, and more! The toppings included licorice salt, charcoal salt, ponzu sauce, marinated radish, seaweed crackers, cod topped with truffle, and some delicious sake to wash it all down! The menu changes with the season, as new fish swim in, and we hope to be back to catch the next batch. Besides a fun and delicious kosher night out, the proceeds go to the #Chabad !

Mazel tov to Team Ranger! The Orthodox Jewish robotics team from Jerusalem competed in an international robotics competition in Australia earlier this month after placing second in the national competition in Israel. The team is made up of middle school kids — both boys and girls — who work to create a robot and solve a problem in Israeli society. They then present those things at the international event. They do all of this with science and coding. At the competition, the team earned the Rising All-Star Award, which celebrates a team that the judges expect great things from in the future.

The competition took place over several days, including Shabbat. The competition enabled them to observe Shabbat without penalty and to explain to the other teams what was going on, they made a display to explain why they weren't there, spreading the meaning and beauty of Shabbat with others.

May they continue to have success in all their efforts with robotics and beyond.

EXCITING UPDATE 🎉 🥳 When we founded the JITC Hollywood Bureau in 2022, the plan was clear. Do all of the things the other Hollywood Bureaus do. Other minority groups have been advocating directly to Hollywood for DECADES. But no one ever did this for the Jews before us, because too many people- Jews included- have bought into tropes of Jewish power and wealth. 

Many of the studios we met with asked if there is data to back up the tropes and stereotypes we've told them we see. The kind of data we are looking for doesn't exist yet. That's why we're thrilled to announce that just like several other Hollywood Bureaus have done before us, JITC Hollywood Bureau is collaborating with the USC Norman Lear Center, one of the leading academic entertainment institutions in Hollywood, to study how Jews -- secular and Orthodox -- are represented in scripted TV. We’re testing to find out how often Jewish characters in TV shows are portrayed in ways that are consistent with stereotypes and tropes, in addition to portrayals of Orthodox Judaism as something to be escaped. 

Once we have this data, we expect to be able to advocate more effectively to the partners we've established relationships with over the last year and a half. We have been fighting for better representation of Jews for almost 18 years. This is a BIG win for those efforts. 

As you can imagine, studies are not inexpensive. And August is CHANGE MAKER Month. The month where we ask you to step forward and support the groundbreaking work we do by becoming a monthly donor. Any monthly amount makes you a CHANGE MAKER. Dream with us. Build with us. Change the world with us. Change Maker info in bio. #representationmatters #jewishrepresentation

“We are Your treasure. You are our Beloved.” 

We say this prayer over and over again on Yom Kippur. Why? Perhaps because if we don’t know how precious we are to God, then it might not be emotionally safe to assess our flaws. If we think that we are worthless, how painful would it be to enumerate our mistakes? 

If we know that we are the precious children of our Father in Heaven who delights in us, then self-assessment comes from our desire to grow and actualize our potential. We can feel proud that we are growth-oriented and know that our Keeper, our King, our Shepherd is proud of us too. 

#gmarchasimatova #gmarchatimatova #selflove #yomkippur

Over Yom Kippur, I got to the first instance that Jews were made to wear the yellow star as an act of shaming. It wasn’t during Nazi Germany, as we’ve been led to believe. When the Cairo Geniza was discovered, it described the Muslim caliphate of the Abbasids based in Baghdad in the 8th century as the first group to institute this practice. Not only did the Jews have to wear these yellow badges on their headgear and necks, the women had to wear one black shoe and one red shoe. They had to wear small bells around their necks or shoes.

All of these acts were done in order to shame and humiliate the Jews of the time, just as the pointy hats the Jews were made to wear after the two Church councils of 1267 was an act of degradation. After thousands of years of antisemites blaming and shaming our people, it is no wonder that so many Jews today have internalized those feelings.

Read more of this story at our link in bio. 

#JewishPride #Hollywood #antisemitism

Jews are a family, a diverse family. That means we’re going to disagree on somethings. We need to be OK with that and find a way to co-exist. In Israel during Yom Kippur, there was a clash between Orthodox Jews praying with a mechitzah (divider) and secular Jews who oppose that. 

We can’t impose our will on others, as long as they are not hurting anyone but we also have to be OK with our Jewish brothers and sisters making different choices that we do. 

Both sides need to get out of the mindset of fixing the other side. There is so much that we do share in common. There are so many ways to celebrate a magnificent history, culture, values. Let’s try to make that our focus. 
#jewishunity #israel #yomkippur

The more I got into the news and social media posts after that, the more I realized that the inverse is true. Today a Muslim woman came to our page to tell me that while Israel used to be the land of the Jews, we angered God and He took our land away from us. She told me nowhere does it say that we’ll ever get it back, “unless the Torah changed.” 

I told her that the Torah did not change and I found the source for her, where it does indeed say that God will gather in the exiles and return us to our land. 

I told her we desperately want to live in peace. And we just want a small sliver of land for the Jewish nation, as Muslims have over 50 countries and Arabs have 22. She then told me the Muslim countries would unite and bring death to Israel. I told her I would pray for the darkness in her soul, that peace would prevail over a murderous ideology. 

I then thanked her for giving me a reason to see the Torah’s message on God returning us to our land from the corners of the earth. I told her I would share this message with our followers, because we have merited to see millennia old prophecies in our days. And light will always overcome darkness. So don’t lose hope. #prayforisrael

Baghdad was also home to a sizable Jewish diaspora around this time. The presence of Jews in what is now Iraq began with the Babylonian exile of 597 BCE. But even after the Persians conquered Babylon and allowed us to return to our homeland, many chose to remain behind.

As the Arab conquests swept over Baghdad, its Jewish population was corralled into ghettos, forced into apartheid-like conditions, and made to wear yellow badges (no, the idea did not originate with Hitler). Although the Karkh district of Baghdad is featured in the game, its Jewish quarter is not. In fact, Jews do not appear at any point in the game’s story.

Arabs and Persians make up the majority of the game’s main cast and NPCs, with the rest being a combination of Turks, Zanj (Bantu-speaking peoples from Southeast Africa who had been taken as slaves), and Chinese and Greek travelers.

In other words, Ubisoft went to the effort of including Chinese and Greek characters in the game, but could not be bothered to include indigenous Middle Eastern minorities. 

Read more at our link in bio.

#JewishRepresentation #JewsInMedia #GamingRepresentation #IndigenousVoices #AssassinsCreedMirage

To My Youngest On His Bar Mitzvah 

The name Rafael means “God heals.” Rafi has always been a “healer” because he is a person who holds other people’s pain. When his siblings cry, he cries with them. When a kid is sad and alone at school, he notices them and comforts them. When a crossing guard helps Rafi cross the road, he tells them “Have a great day!” When a teacher is being ignored by classmates, Rafi makes sure to be extra attentive and respectful.

Rafi’s second name is Dovid. Dovid famously battled the mighty Goliath. Though he was small, Dovid had the courage to stand up to the big guy and vanquish him. When Rafi was a baby, he used to suck his thumb. As he became a toddler, he continued to suck his thumb. I was trying to encourage him to stop sucking his thumb around his third birthday, so I playfully pulled his thumb out of his mouth.

Rafi was NOT having it. “Is this your fum?” he asked. “Is this YOUR fum? No, this is NOT your fum,” Rafi extorted. And Rafi proceeded to suck his thumb. I had to give it to him. Rafi took me on and vanquished me. I was bigger, but I had no response. It was not my thumb. Thankfully, Rafi stopped sucking his thumb (when he was ready).

He Who blessed our forefathers Abraham, Isaac and Jacob - may He bless the fighters of the Israel Defense Force, who stand guard over our land and the cities of our God from the border of the Lebanon to the desert of Egypt, and from the Great Sea unto the approach of the Aravah, on the land, in the air, and on the sea.
May Hashem cause the enemies who rise up against us to be struck down before them. May the Holy One, Blessed is He, preserve and rescue our fighting men from every trouble and distress and from every plague and illness, and may He send blessing and success in their every endeavor.

Hashem was with us then, and to this day, we celebrate our miraculous victory: a tiny people against a mighty army. We celebrate the miracle of a light lasting longer than it should have. 

Today, the tiny country of Israel is once again fighting for its survival, as the terror regime in Iran engages in a multi-front war against our brothers and sisters, both militarily and in media. The more they lie about the historical ties to our land, the more we must educate ourselves about them. The more they accuse of us wanton violence, the more we must learn about our values of peace and life. The more they invalidate our connection to Israel, the more we must strength it. 

Once again, Hashem is with us. We will win this war and our light, as we are a light unto the nations, will last longer than anyone expected, because our existence and survival is a miracle. Chag Sameach and Am Yisrael Chai!

Anti-Zionists have long insisted (in English, at least) that they don’t hate Jews – only “Zionists”.

You see, unlike those vulgar Nazis, they aren’t so barbaric as to oppose our existence outright. They’re only, quite understandably, uncomfortable with this absurd notion – passed down to us by Herzl et al – that we are equal to non-Jews. It’s simply outrageous. Just who do we think we are anyway?

And so the anti-Zionist offered us a deal. All we had to do was join them in their crusade against Jewish self-determination. Give it a kosher stamp of approval. Fashion ourselves a new identity – a new understanding of Jewishness centered on unconditional allyship to gentile minorities who, by dint of their non-Jewishness, are clearly more deserving of support than we could ever hope to be.

Similarly, the Hellenist Greeks said, we don’t hate Jews, we just hate your dumb traditions. Just be good Hellenist Jews and drop those backwards and outdated practices and you can live side by side with us.

The Maccabim did not accept this conditional, pared down version of Jewishness in their time and we shouldn’t accept it in ours.

This scene is not from Israel. It’s from Monsey, New York, four years ago today. On the seventh night of the Chanukah in 2019, a man wielding a machete invaded the home of a Hasidic rabbi in Monsey, who was hosting a Chanukah party.  The assailant began hacking up Jews. Five men were wounded, two of whom were hospitalized in critical condition. 

Joseph Gluck, who was 32 at the time, managed to throw a coffee table at the assailant. Gluck got a young victim out of the way before luring the attacker out of the house, making himself into a target. Afterwards Gluck received an honor for his heroic acts that night. 

Three months after the stabbing, the most severely injured victim, Rabbi Josef Neumann, aged 72, died of his wounds.

The media blamed the Jews. They cited school board issues and noted that the assailant had acted as a “Shabbos goy” - a non-Jew who helps Jews on the sabbath perform forbidden work to try to give “context” to the brutal attack. 

Jews attacked, heroes among us and the world justifying the evil done to us. 

The story doesn’t change while we are in exile, but we are. We are changing. We are waking up, uniting, returning. We’ll remember our fallen, honor our heroes and strengthen ourselves as Jews. And one day we will merit to see the light of our final salvation. #monseystabbing

Today was surreal. A message that we’ve been promoting in Hollywood for the last couple of years, since launching the JITC Hollywood Bureau, just got validated and championed by some of the biggest people working in the industry. 

Change happens over decades and over days. Decades of advocating for better representation of Jews. Months of editing a letter to @theacademy to let them know that it is not OK to exclude Jews from diversity standards, to let them know that Jewish representation has been problematic from the start and that Jews also deserve proud and authentic depictions. In an age of growing Jew hatred, this is life and death. When we drafted this letter, we didn’t want to just ask to be included, we wanted to ask for systemic and practical changes to create the proud Jewish depictions we know are possible. We didn’t know if our letter would catch on. We didn’t know if we’d get any press. In Judaism, we are meant to do our part and let Hashem do the rest. Well we did our part and so did Hashem! We got dozens of the biggest names in entertainment to sign and hundreds of signatures and the press coverage keeps coming! 

You don’t say the sch’hechiyanu blessing for a positive development for the Jewish people but I am grateful to our amazing team, our donors, our followers and these proud Jews in Hollywood for having the moral courage to stand up. And I thank God for sustaining me and bringing me to this day. It’s one that I dreamed of for some time. May it only be the beginning! 

Full article in @thewrap in link in bio.

UPDATE: thank you @amyschumer and @jalexander1959 for signing too!

The letter. (We just included a screen shot of the top signatories when it was sent. More top industry professionals have since signed on, and we are at over 400 signatures.) People want to know how we got these top names on it. Years of tireless work and days of the message getting passed to the right people and it resonating. And it pains me to say it, but the tragedy of October 7, that we continue to suffer from, has ignited and united our people. I don’t think we are ever going back to pre-October 7. And so the Jewish people will fight for our dignity our humanity and our lives. Our team is honored that we got to be the conduit for this message to go out and so proud of the courageous Jews who made this story explode. We have been dreaming of a day when proud and authentic Jewish depictions are the norm, not the exception, and we just got a whole lot closer.
